meanings.def: the place believed to be the home of devils and where bad people go after death
examples: He was terrified of going to hell when he died.
in hell They were threatened with spending eternity in hell.
Lava poured out of the volcano, glowing like the fires of hell.
tormented souls in hell

meanings.def: a very unpleasant experience or situation in which people suffer very much
examples: The last three months have been hell.
He went through hell during the trial.
Her parents made her life hell.
Being totally alone is my idea of hell on earth.
He was in a hell of his own making.
in hell For the last few weeks my whole family has been in hell because of this.
hell for somebody Since she moved in, life has been hell for the other residents.
it is hell doing something It was hell getting through airport security.
I'm never going to escape this hell.
It was sheer hell having to sit through hours of boring lectures!

meanings.def: a swear word that some people use when they are annoyed or surprised or to emphasize something. Its use is offensive to some people.
examples: Oh hell, I've burned the pan.
What the hell do you think you are doing?
Go to hell!
I can't really afford it, but, what the hell (= it doesn't matter), I'll get it anyway.
He's as guilty as hell.
(North American English) ‘Do you understand?’ ‘Hell, no. I don't.’

meanings.def: suddenly there was a lot of noise, arguing, fighting, etc.
examples: There was a loud bang and then all hell broke loose.

meanings.def: to hit somebody/something very hard
examples: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

meanings.def: to annoy somebody very much
examples: The song just bugs the hell out of me.
Those two idiots bug the shit out of me.

meanings.def: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something
examples: If your dad finds out you'll really catch hell!

meanings.def: a lot of trouble
examples: There'll be hell to pay when he finds out.

meanings.def: just for fun; for no real reason
examples: They stole the car just for the hell of it.

meanings.def: used to describe a very unpleasant person or thing; the worst that you can imagine
examples: They are the neighbours from hell.
It really was the holiday from hell—it rained all the time, we all got colds, and we missed the plane home.
She's the girlfriend from hell—I don't know know why he puts up with her.

meanings.def: to leave a place very quickly
examples: Let's get the hell out of here.

meanings.def: to make life unpleasant for somebody
examples: He used to give his mother hell when he was a teenager.
My new shoes are giving me hell (= are hurting me).

meanings.def: to shout at or speak angrily to somebody
examples: Dad will give us hell when he sees that mess.

meanings.def: to get into a very bad state
examples: This firm's gone to hell in a handbasket since the new management took over.

meanings.def: as quickly as possible
examples: to ride hell for leather

meanings.def: used to refer to somebody, usually a woman, who has reacted very angrily to something, especially the fact that her husband or partner has been unfaithful
used to give emphasis to what a person is saying
examples: The firm was in a hell of a mess when he took over.
This holiday is going to cost a hell of a lot of money.
It must have been one hell of a party.
It’s taken him a hell of a long time to get here.
That's one helluva big house you've got.

meanings.def: despite any difficulties
examples: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

meanings.def: used to express anger or surprise
examples: Hell’s teeth, I promised I’d be back by two.

meanings.def: very fast
examples: She was driving like a bat out of hell.

meanings.def: used for emphasis
examples: She worked like hell for her exams.
My broken finger hurt like hell.

meanings.def: used when you are refusing permission or saying that something is not true
examples: ‘I'm coming with you.’ ‘Like hell you are (= you certainly are not).’

meanings.def: to have no chance at all
to have no chance at all
examples: She doesn't have a hope of winning.
You don't have a hope in hell of finding a job.

meanings.def: to have no chance at all
examples: There isn't a snowball's chance in hell that I'll wear that thing!

meanings.def: to affect something/somebody badly
examples: Driving on these rough roads has played hell with my tyres.

meanings.def: to protest angrily, especially in a way that causes trouble for somebody
it is not enough to intend to do good things; you must actually do them
to frighten, annoy, etc. somebody very much
used to say that somebody has been through a difficult situation
examples: We'd been to hell and back together and we were still good friends.

meanings.def: used to express anger or dislike and to say that you no longer care about somebody/something and will take no notice of them
examples: ‘To hell with him,’ she thought, ‘I'm leaving.’
